content.heroSection:
Orlando, FL Workers’ Comp Lawyers

Injured on the job? If you have suffered due to a workplace accident, you are owed compensation for your injuries and hours of lost work. Fortunately, your workers’ comp plan is in place to pay for what you need. Unfortunately, accessing those damages is not always easy. Employers and insurance companies can work against you to protect their bottom lines.

The Orlando workers’ comp lawyers of Vasquez Law Firm, PLLC, can help you get access to the resources you need so you can have peace of mind while you heal. We create tailored strategies to address your legal needs and help you receive the full payment so you can bounce back from your injuries and move forward with your life. 

Reach out for a free initial consultation and learn more about how we can make a difference in your workers’ comp claims. 

A Short Guide To Workplace Injuries

For many people, they imagine workplace injuries are limited to construction sites and factories, which is not always the case. In fact, workplace injuries can happen in restaurants, offices, warehouses, and more. Injuries can be big or small, but all deserve the full amount of compensation needed in order to heal.

Here are a few common types of workplace injuries:

  • Overexertion and heavy lifting: These types of injuries are among the most common types of injuries in U.S. workplaces. Lifting heavy objects, especially incorrectly, carries risks that include sprains, breaks, and debilitating back injuries. 
  • Repetitive motion injuries: Do you type all day? Do you find yourself performing the same basic tasks? Though it might not seem like it, doing the same movements over and over again can cause muscle deterioration, sprain, and eventually permanent injury. You might not think that typing carries a huge risk, for example, but it can lead to carpal tunnel syndrome! Other similar small repetitive tasks can also make a difference for your health. 
  • Equipment-related injuries: Sometimes, equipment backfires, and it can mean serious repercussions for the people who work with it. Whether the reason is negligence, malfunction, improper maintenance, or chemical corrosion, working with equipment of any kind can be a risk to your health. 
  • Construction site injuries: There is a reason people think of construction sites when they think of workplace injury. In addition to the risks posed by equipment, construction workers also have to worry about falls, explosions, and structural collapses. 
  • Mental health impairment: If you were injured on the job and it led to a decline in your mental health, you are owed damages for treatment. Injury can lead to depression, anxiety, PTSD, and a whole host of other poor mental health conditions. In order to get you back on your feet, treating your mental health is just as important as treating your physical health. 

How Our Orlando Workers’ Comp Lawyers Can Help You

It’s nice to think that our employers have our back and our insurance policies will keep us protected. Unfortunately, this is not always the reality. In order to protect their bottom lines, employers and insurers might deny your workers’ comp claim or pay you less than what you are owed so that you have trouble accessing your full compensation down the line.

Our Orlando workers’ comp lawyers want to make sure you are protected. We will assess what you are owed and go after the full amount so you can heal with peace of mind. 

Vasquez Law Firm, PLLC, Can Give You An Advantage

After a workplace accident, you deserve to heal without having to worry about whether you will be in a financial position to fully recover. Vasquez Law Firm, PLLC, can help make the case you need. Reach out for a free initial consultation and learn more about the services we offer. Our goal is to secure the compensation you deserve! 

Frequently Asked Questions

Is workers’ comp taxed?

No, you will not have to pay taxes on your payout. The money is fully intended to help you with your medical needs.

Is there a time limit on when I need to submit my workers’ comp claim? 

In Florida, you have only 30 days following your injury to notify your employer of your injury. After that, you have two years in which to submit your claim for workers’ comp.

Will workers’ comp cover funeral costs if an employee dies as a result of a workplace injury?

Yes. If a worker dies as a result of a workplace accident, workers’ comp can cover funeral expenses. 

 

Practice Areas

  • Orlando, FL Auto Accident Lawyers
  • Orlando, FL Immigration Lawyers
  • Orlando, FL Workers’ Comp Lawyers
